awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CIF: Small: Communication, Storage, Complexity, and Security: A Holistic View on the Fundamental Limits and Code Designs for Private Information Retrieval
awd_abstract_narration:
Powerful and ubiquitous sensors and devices nowadays can collect data on all types of human activities and natural phenomena. These data sets are usually aggregated and stored in a distributed storage system, from which information can then be retrieved as needed for processing and computation. Making such systems private and secure is of paramount importance, which has motivated the study of private information retrieval (PIR) systems, which can provide strong privacy guarantees on the access to information in these databases. Characterizing the level of guarantees will help assess the usefulness of a PIR system. This project aims to develop a holistic information theoretic view of PIR systems, which can provide important theoretical guidance on the design of private, secure, and efficient information retrieval systems.
 
In the framework of this holistic view, this project seeks to identify the information theoretic limits and develop efficient code constructions for the optimal tradeoffs between important system constraints, including communication, storage, complexity, and security. This holistic view goes beyond many information theoretic studies that focus on a single aspect of the system constraints, namely the communication cost. The project is expected to significantly advance the state-of-the-art: it seeks to provide a better balanced and comprehensive understanding on the tradeoffs between different constraints in general information retrieval systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops a holistic view of private information retrieval systems where data is collected in a distributed manner while the privacy of user behavior is protected, using information theory tools. Theoretical guarantees are derived for various performance metrics of such distributed systems, including communication rate (how much data needs to be downloaded for desired information retrieval), storage cost (how much data needs to be stored at distributed storage nodes), computational complexity (how much computation needs to be performed for retrieval), and security and privacy levels (how much undesired information can be revealed and how much collusion may be tolerated) and the tradeoff among the metrics.

New problems are formulated that include a storage code design problem which allows and turns out to necessite non-linear codes (rare in the literature), a problem with multiple levels of privacy where files with different importance level may tolerate different number of colluding servers, and a multi-user retrieval problem which allows users with distinct storage capabilities to simultaneously access data privately and jointly use the communication resource. New solutions are found that generalize traditional random coding and binning tools from classical information theory, introduce new alignment linear structures to recursive private retrieval protocols, symmetry guided and forced code constructions, tree structure based lower bounding analysis, reveal connection to other significant problems in security and privacy. A more comprehensive and balanced understanding of the fundamental limits of the tradeoff between the diverse array of performance metrics is obtained in general information retrieval systems.

Results from this project have been published as IEEE journal articles and have been presented at conference talks, including two tutorials, one at 2021 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory and one at 2024 IEEE International Conference on Communications, for broad audience in the general field of information theory and communications. Three Ph.D. graduate students participated in the research at various stages of this project and gained experience in information theory and coding research. Education materials produced from this project have been discussed in graduate level information theory and seminar classes.

Modified by: Hua Sun
